channel.title: Tofu: The Varieties
channel.description: Recent content on Tofu: The Varieties

item.title: Silken Tofu
item.description: what: Silken tofu is typically undrained, unpressed Japanese-style tofu with the highest water content and a custardy texture. Ultra-smooth and jiggly soft, silken tofu is most commonly used for pur√©eing as a base for soups, dips, and sauces. It also makes excellent dessert puddings and pie fillings. suggested recipes: protein shake, vegan mayo, creamy dips, gravy dishes

item.title: Regular Tofu
item.description: what: Also called “block” tofu or “medium” tofu. Used very commonly for generic cooking purposes. It has a somewhat spongy texture and retains moisture normally, and the other types of tofu are generally labeled on the basis of their water retention. suggested recipes: scrambles, as cubes in soups, stir-frys

item.title: Firm Tofu
item.description: what: This tofu absorbs flavors well and can be stir-fried and pan-fried (how well it will hold together depends on the brand). Think of good, seasoned firm tofu as a substitute for crumbled ricotta cheese. suggested recipes: scrambles, cheese alternatives (block)

item.title: Extra Firm Tofu
item.description: what: This tofu boasts of amazing shape retention and is pretty close to ground meat texture when cooked right. It’s excellent for slicing, cubing, and pan-/stir-/deep-frying. It can be baked or grilled as well. suggested recipes: grilling recipes, substitute for cottage cheese/paneer, in-sauce stir-frys

item.title: Super Firm Tofu
item.description: what: The tofu with the least amount of water retention. Super firm tofu is very dense with a high protein content, and really low moisture so it makes for quick baking/grilling recipes. suggested recipes: grilling, cheese alternatives, stir-frys
